article.title: Sparse Polynomial Chaos Expansions via Compressed Sensing and D-optimal Design

choices: The effect of polynomial order on the accuracy of D-optimal designs.
The empirical CDFs of |M̃|¹/ᴾ for D-optimal designs generated with standard Monte Carlo and coherence-optimal sampling.
The computational cost of generating D-optimal designs with different sampling strategies.
The impact of the number of candidate samples (M) on the quality of D-optimal designs.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from Figure 2 regarding coherence-optimal sampling for D-optimal designs when d > p?
choices: Coherence-optimal sampling leads to significantly better D-optimal designs compared to standard Monte Carlo sampling.
Coherence-optimal sampling performs worse than standard Monte Carlo sampling for generating D-optimal designs.
Coherence-optimal sampling provides slightly better D-optimal designs compared to standard Monte Carlo sampling.
There is no noticeable difference in the quality of D-optimal designs generated with either sampling strategy.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the term  'ε' represent in formula (35)?
choices: The truncation error of the PC expansion.
The weight function applied to the QoI values.
The vector of exact PC coefficients.
Additive noise applied to the weighted QoI values.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the trend observed in Figure 7 regarding the relative error in estimating the displacement u(Ξ,4) as the sample size (N) increases?
choices: The relative error increases for all three sampling strategies.
The relative error decreases for all three sampling strategies.
The relative error remains constant for all three sampling strategies.
The relative error fluctuates randomly for all three sampling strategies.
